button.label: &Model
button.supertip: Build or edit your optimization model. Will detect and load any pre-existing model built with Solver, and will save the results to the sheet in a Solver-friendly way.

button.label: &Model...
button.supertip: Build or edit your optimization model. Will detect and load any pre-existing model built with Solver, and will save the results to the sheet in a Solver-friendly way.

button.label: &Quick AutoModel
button.supertip: Run AutoModel with default options. No dialog menu will appear, so for well-structured sheets it is unnecessary to run through the full AutoModel procedure step-by-step for small changes.

button.label: &AutoModel And Solve
button.screentip: Run AutoModel with default options and then solve problem
button.supertip: Run AutoModel with default options and then solve the problem. No dialog menu will appear, so for well-structured sheets it is unnecessary to run through the full AutoModel procedure step-by-step for small changes.

button.label: &Solver Engine...
button.supertip: Choose your solver: CBC (default), Gurobi, or NOMAD (non-linear).

button.label: &Options...
button.supertip: Set options: linearity, non-negativity, max solve time, tolerance.

button.label: &Solve
button.supertip: Solve an existing Solver model on the active worksheet by constructing the model's equations and then calling the current chosen optimization engine.

button.label: &Solve
button.supertip: Solve an existing Solver model on the active worksheet by constructing the model's equations and then calling the current chosen optimization engine.

button.label: Solve &Relaxation
button.screentip: Solve a modified problem without any integer or binary constraints
button.supertip: Relaxes any integer or binary requirements on the variables, and solves the resulting linear program, typically giving an answer with fractional variables.

button.label: Show/&Hide Model
button.screentip: Show or hide the optimization model on this sheet
button.supertip: OpenSolver will analyse an existing model on the active sheet, and add coloured annotations to the sheet that indicate the variable cells, the objective cell, and the constraints.

button.label: &Quick Solve
button.screentip: Quickly re-solve a model after changing the parameter values
button.supertip: OpenSolver can re-solve problems very quickly if it is first told about the cells (termed parameters) that change between solves. The Quick Solve menu items below can be used to set this up for your model.

button.label: Set QuickSolve Parameters...
button.screentip: Define the parameter cells for QuickSolve
button.supertip: OpenSolver can re-solve problems very quickly if it is first told about the cells (termed parameters) that change between solves. This menu item lets you define the parameter cells. Note that OpenSolver assumes these parameters change the model's constraint right hand sides in a linear fashion.

button.label: Initialize QuickSolve
button.screentip: Construct the model's equations and prepare for QuickSolve
button.supertip: OpenSolver can re-solve problems very quickly if it is first told about the cells (termed parameters) that change between solves. After you have defined the parameter cells, this menu item constructs the model's equations ready for quick solving.

button.label: View Last Model File
button.screentip: View the model file created when OpenSolver last solved a model
button.supertip: For some solvers, OpenSolver writes the model to a temporary text file that is read by the solver. It is often useful to load and view this file.

button.label: View Last Solution File
button.supertip: When a model is solved, a temporary solution file can be created by the solver containing the solution to the optimization problem. It is sometimes useful to load and view this file.

button.label: View Last Solver Log File
button.screentip: View the last solver log file
button.supertip: OpenSolver creates a log file every time a model is solved. The log file contains output from the solver, such as iteration details during the solve, which can give you more information about your model.

button.label: View Last Error Log File
button.screentip: View the last error log file
button.supertip: OpenSolver creates a log file every time an error occurs with detailed information about the error.

button.label: View All OpenSolver Files...
button.supertip: Opens the folder containing all files created while using OpenSolver.

button.label: Open Last Model in CBC...
button.screentip: Open the CBC command line, and load in the last model.
button.supertip: Open the CBC optimizer at the command line, and load in the last model solved by OpenSolver. Type '?' at the CBC command line to get help on the CBC commands, and 'exit' to quit CBC. Note that any solutions generated are discarded; they are not loaded back into your spreadsheet.
